POR.DRECONTENT:
This project produced novel results at the interface between several fields of mathematics: algebraic topology (AT), algebraic geometry (AG), and number theory (NT).  The first set of results applied AG to AT, proving theorems relating elliptic curves (geometric objects governed by certain cubic polynomials) to K(2)-local and v_2-periodic stable homotopy theory (the forefront of our knowledge on how high-dimensional spheres wrap around low-dimensional spheres).  In joint work with Mark Behrens (http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.0076), I produced comutations of Q(3) and Q(5), spectra related to the K(2)-local sphere via modular forms with level structures (certain objects from NT).  In joint work with Behrens, Nat Stapleton, and Vesna Stojanoska (http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.01050), I initiated the study of cooperations in topological modular forms, an AT object built with AG and NT data.  This promises to eventually lead to results on v_2-periodic stable homotopy theory.

The second set of results applied techniques of AT to AG via the study of motivic homotopy theory.  In papers with Paul Arne Ostvaer (http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.5007 and http://arxiv.org/abs/1310.2970), I used spectral sequences to compute algebraic cobordism and motivic stable homotopy groups.  In a paper with Jeremiah Heller (http://arxiv.org/abs/1401.4728), I studied links between equivariant AT (spaces exhibiting certain symmetries encoded) and motivic homotopy theory, proving that certain objects with two-fold symmetry embed faithfully into the stable motivic homotopy category over the real numbers.  This result provides a rigorous interpretation of an analogy between these fields that has inspired researchers over the past decade.

During this grant period, I also served as a mentor to undergraduate researchers including Peter Wear, whose work on double cosets in division algebras is provisionally accepted to the journal Topology and its Applications.


Last Modified: 12/10/2015
Modified by: Kyle M Ormsby

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project produced novel results at the interface between several fields of mathematics: algebraic topology (AT), algebraic geometry (AG), and number theory (NT). The first set of results applied AG to AT, proving theorems relating elliptic curves (geometric objects governed by certain cubic polynomials) to K(2)-local and v_2-periodic stable homotopy theory (the forefront of our knowledge on how high-dimensional spheres wrap around low-dimensional spheres). In joint work with Mark Behrens (http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.0076), I produced comutations of Q(3) and Q(5), spectra related to the K(2)-local sphere via modular forms with level structures (certain objects from NT). In joint work with Behrens, Nat Stapleton, and Vesna Stojanoska (http://arxiv.org/abs/1501.01050), I initiated the study of cooperations in topological modular forms, an AT object built with AG and NT data. This promises to eventually lead to results on v_2-periodic stable homotopy theory. The second set of results applied techniques of AT to AG via the study of motivic homotopy theory. In papers with Paul Arne Ostvaer (http://arxiv.org/abs/1208.5007 and http://arxiv.org/abs/1310.2970), I used spectral sequences to compute algebraic cobordism and motivic stable homotopy groups. In a paper with Jeremiah Heller (http://arxiv.org/abs/1401.4728), I studied links between equivariant AT (spaces exhibiting certain symmetries encoded) and motivic homotopy theory, proving that certain objects with two-fold symmetry embed faithfully into the stable motivic homotopy category over the real numbers. This result provides a rigorous interpretation of an analogy between these fields that has inspired researchers over the past decade. During this grant period, I also served as a mentor to undergraduate researchers including Peter Wear, whose work on double cosets in division algebras is provisionally accepted to the journal Topology and its Applications.
